natural problem: I have two 20-sided dice that each have 4 maroon sides, 7 teal sides, 8 cyan sides, and one sparkly side. If I roll both dice, what is the probability they come up the same?
natural solution: This problem requires a little bit of casework. There are four ways in which the dice can both show the same thing: if they both show maroon, both show teal, both show cyan or both show sparkly. The probability of getting maroon is $\dfrac{4}{20}$, so the probability that they will both show maroon is $\left(\dfrac{4}{20}\right)^2=\dfrac{16}{400}$.

Similarly, the probability of getting teal is $\dfrac{7}{20}$, so the probability that they will both show teal is $\left(\dfrac{7}{20}\right)^2=\dfrac{49}{400}$, the probability of getting cyan is $\dfrac{8}{20}$, so the probability that they will both show cyan is $\left(\dfrac{8}{20}\right)^2=\dfrac{64}{400}$ and the probability of getting sparkly is $\dfrac{1}{20}$, so the probability that they will both get sparkly is $\left(\dfrac{1}{20}\right)^2=\dfrac{1}{400}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes maroon teal cyan sparkly total :: real
assumes h0 : "maroon = 4"
and h1 : "teal = 7"
and h2 : "cyan = 8"
and h3 : "sparkly = 1"
and h4 : "total = 20"
shows  "((maroon/total)*(maroon/total)) + ((teal/total)*(teal/total)) + ((cyan/total)*(cyan/total)) + ((sparkly/total)*(sparkly/total)) = 13 / 40"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have two 20-sided dice that each have 4 maroon sides, 7 teal sides, 8 cyan sides, and one sparkly side. If I roll both dice, what is the probability they come up the same? The final Answer is \dfrac{13}{40}
 ### Proof
 This problem requires a little bit of casework. There are four ways in which the dice can both show the same thing: if they both show maroon, both show teal, both show cyan or both show sparkly. The probability of getting maroon is $\dfrac{4}{20}$, so the probability that they will both show maroon is $\left(\dfrac{4}{20}\right)^2=\dfrac{16}{400}$.
 Similarly, the probability of getting teal is $\dfrac{7}{20}$, so the probability that they will both show teal is $\left(\dfrac{7}{20}\right)^2=\dfrac{49}{400}$, the probability of getting cyan is $\dfrac{8}{20}$, so the probability that they will both show cyan is $\left(\dfrac{8}{20}\right)^2=\dfrac{64}{400}$ and the probability of getting sparkly is $\dfrac{1}{20}$, so the probability that they will both get sparkly is $\left(\dfrac{1}{20}\right)^2=\dfrac{1}{400}$.
 So our answer is $\dfrac{16}{400}+\dfrac{49}{400}+\dfrac{64}{400}+\dfrac{1}{400}=\frac{130}{400}=\boxed{\dfrac{13}{40}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes maroon teal cyan sparkly total :: real
assumes h0 : "maroon = 4"
and h1 : "teal = 7"
and h2 : "cyan = 8"
and h3 : "sparkly = 1"
and h4 : "total = 20"
shows  "((maroon/total)*(maroon/total)) + ((teal/total)*(teal/total)) + ((cyan/total)*(cyan/total)) + ((sparkly/total)*(sparkly/total)) = 13 / 40"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: There are 4 maroon, 7 teal, 8 cyan, and 1 sparkly objects in a collection of 20 objects. Find the sum of the squares of the proportions of each type of object in the collection. The final answer is $\frac{13}{40}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes maroon teal cyan sparkly :: real
assumes h0 : "4 / 20 = maroon"
and h1 : "7 / 20 = teal"
and h2 : "8 / 20 = cyan"
and h3 : "1 / 20 = sparkly"
shows  "((maroon * maroon) + (teal * teal) + (cyan * cyan) + (sparkly * sparkly)) = 13 / 40"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have two 20-sided dice that each have 4 maroon sides, 7 teal sides, 8 cyan sides, and one sparkly side. If I roll both dice, what is the probability they come up the same? The final Answer is \dfrac{13}{40}
 ### Proof
 This problem requires a little bit of casework. There are four ways in which the dice can both show the same thing: if they both show maroon, both show teal, both show cyan or both show sparkly. The probability of getting maroon is $\dfrac{4}{20}$, so the probability that they will both show maroon is $\left(\dfrac{4}{20}\right)^2=\dfrac{16}{400}$.
 Similarly, the probability of getting teal is $\dfrac{7}{20}$, so the probability that they will both show teal is $\left(\dfrac{7}{20}\right)^2=\dfrac{49}{400}$, the probability of getting cyan is $\dfrac{8}{20}$, so the probability that they will both show cyan is $\left(\dfrac{8}{20}\right)^2=\dfrac{64}{400}$ and the probability of getting sparkly is $\dfrac{1}{20}$, so the probability that they will both get sparkly is $\left(\dfrac{1}{20}\right)^2=\dfrac{1}{400}$.
 So our answer is $\dfrac{16}{400}+\dfrac{49}{400}+\dfrac{64}{400}+\dfrac{1}{400}=\frac{130}{400}=\boxed{\dfrac{13}{40}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes maroon teal cyan sparkly :: real
assumes h0 : "4 / 20 = maroon"
and h1 : "7 / 20 = teal"
and h2 : "8 / 20 = cyan"
and h3 : "1 / 20 = sparkly"
shows  "((maroon * maroon) + (teal * teal) + (cyan * cyan) + (sparkly * sparkly)) = 13 / 40"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given that maroon, teal, cyan, and sparkly represent the fractions $\frac{4}{20}$, $\frac{7}{20}$, $\frac{8}{20}$, and $\frac{1}{20}$, respectively, find the sum of the squares of these four numbers. The final answer is $\frac{13}{40}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes maroon teal cyan sparkly :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. maroon i = 4 / 20"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. teal i = 7 / 20"
and h2 : "\<forall>i. cyan i = 8 / 20"
and h3 : "\<forall>i. sparkly i = 1 / 20"
and h4 : "i \<in> {1, 2}"
shows  "maroon 1 * maroon 2 + teal 1 * teal 2 + cyan 1 * cyan 2 + sparkly 1 * sparkly 2 = 13 / 40"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have two 20-sided dice that each have 4 maroon sides, 7 teal sides, 8 cyan sides, and one sparkly side. If I roll both dice, what is the probability they come up the same? The final Answer is \dfrac{13}{40}
 ### Proof
 This problem requires a little bit of casework. There are four ways in which the dice can both show the same thing: if they both show maroon, both show teal, both show cyan or both show sparkly. The probability of getting maroon is $\dfrac{4}{20}$, so the probability that they will both show maroon is $\left(\dfrac{4}{20}\right)^2=\dfrac{16}{400}$.
 Similarly, the probability of getting teal is $\dfrac{7}{20}$, so the probability that they will both show teal is $\left(\dfrac{7}{20}\right)^2=\dfrac{49}{400}$, the probability of getting cyan is $\dfrac{8}{20}$, so the probability that they will both show cyan is $\left(\dfrac{8}{20}\right)^2=\dfrac{64}{400}$ and the probability of getting sparkly is $\dfrac{1}{20}$, so the probability that they will both get sparkly is $\left(\dfrac{1}{20}\right)^2=\dfrac{1}{400}$.

 *)

theorem
fixes maroon teal cyan sparkly :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. maroon i = 4 / 20"
and h1 : "\<forall>i. teal i = 7 / 20"
and h2 : "\<forall>i. cyan i = 8 / 20"
and h3 : "\<forall>i. sparkly i = 1 / 20"
and h4 : "i \<in> {1, 2}"
shows  "maroon 1 * maroon 2 + teal 1 * teal 2 + cyan 1 * cyan 2 + sparkly 1 * sparkly 2 = 13 / 40"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given that maroon, teal, cyan, and sparkly are functions defined for elements in the set {1, 2}, with maroon(i) = 4/20, teal(i) = 7/20, cyan(i) = 8/20, and sparkly(i) = 1/20. Calculate the sum of the products of each function's values for 1 and 2: maroon(1) * maroon(2) + teal(1) * teal(2) + cyan(1) * cyan(2) + sparkly(1) * sparkly(2). The final answer is 13/40.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob_same :: rat
assumes h0 : "prob_same = (4 / 20 * 4 / 20) + (7 / 20 * 7 / 20) + (8 / 20 * 8 / 20) + (1 / 20 * 1 / 20)"
shows  "prob_same = 13 / 40"

fixes prob_same :: rat
assumes h0 : "prob_same = (4 / 20 * 4 / 20) + (7 / 20 * 7 / 20) + (8 / 20 * 8 / 20) + (1 / 20 * 1 / 20)"

fixes maroon teal cyan sparkly total :: real
assumes h0 : "maroon = 4"
and h1 : "teal = 7"
and h2 : "cyan = 8"
and h3 : "sparkly = 1"
and h4 : "total = 20"
shows  "((maroon / total) * (maroon / total) + (teal / total) * (teal / total) + (cyan / total) * (cyan / total) + (sparkly / total) * (sparkly / total)) = 13 / 40"

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes maroon teal cyan sparkly :: real
and die1 die2 prob :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "maroon = 4 / 20"
and h1 : "teal = 7 / 20"
and h2 : "cyan = 8 / 20"
and h3 : "sparkly = 1 / 20"
and h4 : "\<forall> color. prob color = die1 color * die2 color"
shows  "prob maroon + prob teal + prob cyan + prob sparkly = 13 / 40"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have two 20-sided dice that each have 4 maroon sides, 7 teal sides, 8 cyan sides, and one sparkly side. If I roll both dice, what is the probability they come up the same? The final Answer is \dfrac{13}{40}
 ### Proof
 This problem requires a little bit of casework. There are four ways in which the dice can both show the same thing: if they both show maroon, both show teal, both show cyan or both show sparkly. The probability of getting maroon is $\dfrac{4}{20}$, so the probability that they will both show maroon is $\left(\dfrac{4}{20}\right)^2=\dfrac{16}{400}$.
 Similarly, the probability of getting teal is $\dfrac{7}{20}$, so the probability that they will both show teal is $\left(\dfrac{7}{20}\right)^2=\dfrac{49}{400}$, the probability of getting cyan is $\dfrac{8}{20}$, so the probability that they will both show cyan is $\left(\dfrac{8}{20}\right)^2=\dfrac{64}{400}$ and the probability of getting sparkly is $\dfrac{1}{20}$, so the probability that they will both get sparkly is $\left(\dfrac{1}{20}\right)^2=\dfrac{1}{400}$.
 So our answer is $\dfrac{16}{400}+\dfrac{49}{400}+\dfrac{64}{400}+\dfrac{1}{400}=\frac{130}{400}=\boxed{\dfrac{13}{40}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes maroon teal cyan sparkly :: real
and die1 die2 prob :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "maroon = 4 / 20"
and h1 : "teal = 7 / 20"
and h2 : "cyan = 8 / 20"
and h3 : "sparkly = 1 / 20"
and h4 : "\<forall> color. prob color = die1 color * die2 color"
shows  "prob maroon + prob teal + prob cyan + prob sparkly = 13 / 40"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Four colors of marbles are placed in a bag: maroon, teal, cyan, and sparkly. The probability of picking a maroon marble is $\frac{4}{20}$, a teal marble is $\frac{7}{20}$, a cyan marble is $\frac{8}{20}$, and a sparkly marble is $\frac{1}{20}$. Two marbles are picked from the bag, one after the other, without replacement. What is the probability of picking any of the four colors? The final answer is $\frac{13}{40}$.

(* ### Problem

theorem
fixes p_same :: real
assumes h0 : "p_same = (4 / 20) * (4 / 20) + (7 / 20) * (7 / 20) + (8 / 20) * (8 / 20) + (1 / 20) * (1 / 20)"
shows  "p_same = 13 / 40"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given that the probability of drawing the same color ball from a box with 4 red, 7 blue, 8 green, and 1 yellow ball is calculated as $p_{same} = \frac{4}{20} \cdot \frac{4}{20} + \frac{7}{20} \cdot \frac{7}{20} + \frac{8}{20} \cdot \frac{8}{20} + \frac{1}{20} \cdot \frac{1}{20}$. What is the value of $p_{same}$? The final answer is $\frac{13}{40}$.
